title: 108_hr1997
content: The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004, also known as "Laci and Conner's Law," amends Title 18 of the United States Code to include a new chapter, "Protection of Unborn Children," which outlines measures for the protection of unborn children. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004, also known as "Laci and Conner's Law," establishes a separate offense for causing harm to a child in utero. The punishment for this offense is the same as if the injury or death had occurred to the mother. Proof of knowledge of the pregnancy or intent to harm the unborn child is not required. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004, also known as "Laci and Conner's Law," establishes a separate offense for causing harm to a child in utero. The punishment for this offense is the same as if the injury or death had occurred to the mother. Proof of knowledge of the pregnancy or intent to harm the unborn child is not required. The act specifies that if the person intentionally kills or attempts to kill the unborn child, they will be punished under specific sections of the law for intentionally killing or attempting to kill a human being. The death penalty is not imposed for an offense under this section. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004, also known as "Laci and Conner's Law," establishes separate offenses for causing harm to a child in utero. The act specifies that intentional killing or attempting to kill the unborn child will be punished under specific sections of the law. Nothing in this section permits prosecution for conduct relating to abortion with consent, medical treatment of the pregnant woman or her unborn child, or any woman with respect to her unborn child. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004, also known as "Laci and Conner's Law," establishes separate offenses for causing harm to a child in utero. Consent is implied by law for any medical treatment of the pregnant woman or her unborn child, or any woman with respect to her unborn child. The term 'unborn child' refers to a child in utero, a member of the species homo sapiens at any stage of development. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004, known as "Laci and Conner's Law," establishes separate offenses for causing harm to a child in utero. The military justice system has been amended to include protection for unborn children under the Uniform Code of Military Justice. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004, also known as "Laci and Conner's Law," creates separate offenses for causing harm to a child in utero. Any person subject to this law who violates certain provisions and causes harm to an unborn child will face a separate offense with punishment determined by a court-martial. It does not require proof of knowledge or intent regarding the pregnancy. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 establishes separate offenses for causing harm to an unborn child. If a person intentionally kills or attempts to kill the unborn child, they will be punished under specific sections of the law. The death penalty cannot be imposed for offenses under this act. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 establishes separate offenses for causing harm to an unborn child, defining an 'unborn child' as a member of the species homo sapiens at any stage of development in the womb. The act prohibits prosecution for conduct relating to abortion with consent, medical treatment of the pregnant woman or her unborn child, and any woman with respect to her unborn child. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 establishes separate offenses for causing harm to an unborn child, defining an 'unborn child' as a member of the species homo sapiens at any stage of development in the womb. A clerical amendment is made to insert a new item in the table of sections related to death or injury of an unborn child.
